Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Quantifying Feedbacks between Groundwater Decline, Wind Erosion, and Ecological Change in Desert Vegetation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will fund an analysis of the interactions between groundwater, soil and vegetation properties, and desert dust generation. Wind erosion of desert soils is thought to cause irreversible change to ecosystems, and the mobilized particulate matter can seriously degrade air quality. In deserts globally, regions that produce the most dust are characterized by low elevation depressions where wind erodible material has been and continues to be deposited fluvially. Shallow groundwater is often pumped from these regions for agricultural and municipal use. Since water demands are rapidly increasingly in many desert regions, there is increasing need to understand of how groundwater management might influence dust generation. Ideally, information could be attained that would guide groundwater management with the goal of promoting soil stability. This project will utilize measurements of vegetation and soil conditions and wind velocities to model wind erosion at a range of sites that experienced successively greater groundwater fluctuation over the past 20 years. Model results will be compared to direct measurements of recent soil loss using radiogenic fallout isotopes and dust traps. Finally, measurements of soil resource availability (nutrients and soil moisture) will be used to understand feedback processes between groundwater decline, soil loss, and ecosystem changes that might promote continued soil instability.

Broader Impacts: The project will have a broad impact on our understanding of the role water management has on dust and air quality in deserts. The work will form collaborations between academic institutions and regulatory groups in the proposed study region, near Bishop, California. Both the Inyo County Water Department and the Great Basin Unified Air Pollution Control District will provide necessary data to the project and gain important information on how their vegetation and air quality management activities could be tailored to gain long-term sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In deserts, surface water diversion and the inter-basin transfer of surface water are becoming increasingly widespread, and can directly or indirectly impact the environment (e.g., air and water quality, the health of natural vegetation, etc.). Saline lakes, located within basins having no outlet to the sea, are shrinking in size due to water diversions for urban and agricultural uses, exposing salt-crusted playas, and affecting groundwater tables in the surrounding vegetated landscape. Resource managers in these areas have turned to groundwater pumping to supplement surface water during dry years. Intentional groundwater recharge during wet years and pumping during dry years has benefits over surface storage due to lower evaporation rates. However, this management strategy is rarely carried out with consideration of general impacts to the environment. For example, groundwater decline below the reach of plant roots leads to regional decreases in vegetation cover and shifts in composition from grass to shrub-dominated plant communities. Groundwater decline is also thought to influence wind erosion and dust emissions through its interaction with surface crusts, soil moisture, and vegetation structure. This project addressed remaining uncertainties in these processes in Owens Valley, California, where decades of surface water diversion and groundwater pumping by the City of Los Angeles have altered the environment in many ways. We intend our results to further scientific understanding of ecogeomorphic processes in deserts, but also provide needed information to natural resource managers working in water scarce environments.

 

We measured soil erosion in shallow groundwater environments over temporal scales comparable to the record of groundwater pumping and vegetation disturbance. At the shortest timescale, we maintained dust traps for 3 years at sites where we also measured the three-dimensional structure of vegetation to a distance of 50-m from each trap. To study soil stability at longer timescales (months to decades) we used short-lived fallout radioisotopes as markers of soil stability, and compared these measurements to satellite remote sensing observations of vegetation cover over time. We also worked with data from air quality monitors located through out the Owens Valley to assess the degree to which eroded soil makes it into the atmosphere as air pollution. We found that wind erosion in Owens Valley meadows and scrublands results in significant reworking of soils (moves soils short distances), which contributes in some cases to dust emissions and air pollution. We found that when grass cover was above 15%, this effect was minimized. This suggests that when groundwater is within the reach of plant roots (within 2-3 meters of the surface), environmental degradation is manageable. These results were used to parameterize an ecological economic model that simulates the cost of restoring vegetation cover to sites affected by groundwater decline and vegetation dieback, which showed that using an adaptive water management strategy in Owens Valley would provide a more cost-effective means to supply water. Within our scientific discipline, we made several significant advances to the way data is analyzed, we advanced models of wind erosion, and we demonstrated the utility of geochemical techniques for estimating soil stability in deserts. The project resulted in (or contributed to) the training of several new investigators, postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduate students. We have published, or are preparing for publication, 7 manuscripts in the scientific literature and have presented our work over 10 times at international conferences.
